hawaiian_text: A make ‘o Puali‘i, ho‘i akula ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o ā hiki i kona makuahine, iā  Pōka‘ī, noho ihola lāua, ‘a‘ohe ‘ai o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ka ‘ai. I ia wā, e noho ana ‘o  ‘Ama‘u he ali‘i no O‘ahu nei, ma Waikīkī kahi i noho ai, hele maila kekahi kanaka no Honouliuli  mai ā hiki ma Waikīkī, e noho ana ke ali‘i. ‘Ōlelo  akula ia: “E ke alii ē\! He ‘oi kahi keiki ‘u‘uku ikaika  loa, ua make kona makua kāne a ua kiola ‘ia kona  po‘o i kai loa, he wahi lō‘ihi loa, ‘elima mile ka  lō‘ihi. A lohe o ‘Ama‘u, aia kona ikaika a make au iā  ia, akā, i ‘ole au e make iā ia ‘a‘ohe ona ikaika. Iā ia  e ‘ōlelo ana ma Waikīkī, ua lohe nō ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kēia mau ‘ōlelo nona.
gpt-4_1-nano_translation: A prince named Puali‘i, then Nāmakaokapāo‘o arrived and went to his mother, Pōka‘ī, where they stayed; Nāmakaokapāo‘o did not eat the food. At that time, a chief named ‘Ama‘u from O‘ahu, residing at Waikīkī, where he lived, came on a messenger from Honouliuli to Waikīkī to meet the chief. The messenger said: “O king! There is a small, very strong child, whose father has died and whose head was cut off at sea, a very distant place, about five miles away. When ‘Ama‘u heard this, about the child’s strength and death, he said he would not die for him, that he had no strength. As he was speaking at Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo‘o overheard these words of his.”
gpt-4_1-nano_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>
A prince named Puali‘i, then Nāmakaokapāo‘o arrived and went to his mother, Pōka‘ī, where they stayed; Nāmakaokapāo‘o did not eat the food. At that time, a chief named ‘Ama‘u from O‘ahu, residing at Waikīkī, where he lived, came on a messenger from Honouliuli to Waikīkī to meet the chief. The messenger said: “O king! There is a small, very strong child, whose father has died and whose head was cut off at sea, a very distant place, about five miles away. When ‘Ama‘u heard this, about the child’s strength and death, he said he would not die for him, that he had no strength. As he was speaking at Waikīkī, Nāmakaokapāo‘o overheard these words of his.”
</translation>

<commentary>
• Allegorical Representation of Power and Resistance
  – The characters—Puali‘i, Nāmakaokapāo‘o, Pōka‘ī, and ‘Ama‘u—may symbolize different factions or spirits within Hawaiian society, particularly during the post-contact period of social upheaval.
  – The mention of Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s abstention from food can be an allegory for spiritual or political purity, or resistance to certain influences, tying into traditional stories of mo‘olelo that encode social virtue.
  
• Names and Their Symbolic Significance
  – Nāmakaokapāo‘o: ‘Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’—“the eyes of the Pāo‘o,” which could symbolize vigilance or prophetic insight; Pāo‘o might be a specific place or spiritual concept.
  – Pōka‘ī: “The night’s cry” or “darkness,” possibly representing the maternal/life-giving force or even the “protector” in cultural symbolism.
  – ‘Ama‘u: “The wild ginger” or “Hibiscus,” a name often associated with strength or warrior characteristics; historically, ‘Ama‘u was also a legendary chief—symbol for leadership or territorial claim.
  
• Numerical and Geographical Symbolism
  – The mention of “five miles” could symbolize a significant boundary or distance that denotes a journey or spiritual separation.
  – The geographical references, Waikīkī and Honouliuli, embody important cultural landscapes connected to territorial boundaries and social networks.
  
• Cultural Context and Social Commentary
  – The narrative hints at themes of kinship, political allegiance, and perhaps rivalry, especially as ‘Ama‘u dismisses the threat, signifying resilience or defiance.
  – The overhearing of words by Nāmakaokapāo‘o suggests the importance of omens, prophecy, or the importance of listening—an essential Hawaiian value linked to spirituality and plain speech.
  – The story may reflect the complexities in Hawaiian leadership, alliances, and conflicts during the late pre-contact or early contact era, especially amidst the upheavals of the Ai Kapu era or post-1819 social reorder after the abolition of the kapu system.
  
• Broader Themes
  – The underlying message can be read as a critique of bravado versus true strength, or the importance of spiritual and moral endurance against threats.
  – The narrative also encodes social hierarchy and the significance of kākau and genealogy in legitimizing authority during turbulent times.
</commentary>
reference_translation: When Puali‘i died, Nāmakaokapāo‘o went back  to his mother, Pōka‘ī, and the two lived together,  but Nāmakaokapāo‘o had nothing to eat. At that  time, ‘Ama‘u was a chief of O‘ahu in Waikīkī,  where he lived. A man of Honouliuli came to Waikīkī, where the chief was found. The man said,  “Chief, there is a little boy who is amazingly strong.  He killed his father and threw his head in the  ocean a really long distance away, five miles off.”  When ‘Ama‘u heard this, he said, “We’ll see how  strong he is if he kills me. But if he doesn’t kill me,  he isn’t strong at all.” When he said this in Waikīkī,  Nāmakaokapāo‘o heard what he was saying about  him.
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14**• From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of  Christianity’s defeat over the ‘Ai Kapu, with   Nāmakaokapāo‘o representing progressive   Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his  mother, Pōka‘ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians’ futile attempts to hold onto ‘Ai Kapu culture.
